hints_html:
To evaluate the derivative of a multivariable function g = g(x,y) with respect to t where x,y are functions of t, we need to use the chain rule for multivariable functions:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dg}{dt} = \frac{\partial g}{\partial x}\frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{\partial g}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{dt} = g_{x}\frac{dx}{dt} + g_{y}\frac{dy}{dt}.\end{aligned}\]

After applying the multivariable chain rule to \(f\) once, you will need to apply it again to d\(f\)/dt since the partial derivatives of \(f\) are also functions of x, y.

You will also need the product rule.
hints_latex:
After applying the multivariable chain rule to \emph{$f$} once, you will
need to apply it again to \emph{d$f$/dt} since the partial derivatives of
\emph{$f$} are also functions of \emph{x}, \emph{y}.

You will also need the product rule.
hints_raw:
To evaluate the derivative of a multivariable function g = g(x,y) with respect to t where x,y are functions of t, we need to use the <b>chain rule</b> for multivariable functions:

:<math>
\frac{dg}{dt} = \frac{\partial g}{\partial x}\frac{dx}{dt} + \frac{\partial g}{\partial y}\frac{dy}{dt} = g_{x}\frac{dx}{dt} + g_{y}\frac{dy}{dt}.
</math>
After applying the multivariable chain rule to ''&fnof;'' once, you will need to apply it again to ''d&fnof;/dt'' since the partial derivatives of ''&fnof;'' are also functions of ''x'', ''y''.

You will also need the product rule.
sols_html:
First we evaluate the first derivative of z with respect to t using the multivariable chain rule.

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dz}{dt} &= f_{x}\frac{dx}{dt} + f_{y}\frac{dy}{dt} &= f_{x}\cdot 4t + f_{y}\cdot 3t^{2}\end{aligned}\]

We then take the next derivative of z by taking the derivative with respect to t of the above result, using the multivariable chain rule again as well as the product rule.

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}} &= \frac{d}{dt}\left(f_{x}\cdot 4t + f_{y}\cdot 3t^{2}\right) \\ &= 4t(f_{xx}\cdot 4t + f_{xy}\cdot 3t^{2}) + 4f_{x} + 3t^{2}(f_{yx}\cdot 4t + f_{yy} 3t^{2}) + 6t \cdot f_{y}\end{aligned}\]

Next, we recognize that if t = 1, then (x,y) = (2,1). Thus, we can use the information given in the question about the partial derivatives of f to evaluate \(d^{2}z/dt^{2}\) at t = 1:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}} &= 4t(f_{xx}\cdot 4t + f_{xy}\cdot 3t^{2}) + 4f_{x} + 3t^{2}(f_{yx}\cdot 4t + f_{yy} 3t^{2}) + 6t \cdot f_{y} \\ \frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}}\Big\vert_{t = 1} &= 4(2(4) + 3) + 4(5) + 3(4 - 4(3)) + 6(-2) \\ &= 4(11) + 20 + 3(-8) - 12 = 28\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, \({\color{blue} \frac{d^{2}z}{dt^{2}}\Big\vert_{t = 1} =28}.\)
statement_html:
Let \(\displaystyle z=f(x,y)\), where \(\displaystyle f(x,y)\) has continuous second order partial derivatives, and

\[\begin{aligned} x&=2t^2, & y&=t^3, & & \\ f_x(2,1)&=5, & f_y(2,1)&=-2, & & \\ f_{xx}(2,1)&=2, & f_{xy}(2,1)&=1, & f_{yy}(2,1)&=-4\end{aligned}\]

Find \(\frac{\textrm{d}^2z}{\textrm{d}t^2}\) when t=1.
statement_latex:
Let $\displaystyle z=f(x,y)$, where $\displaystyle f(x,y)$ has
continuous second order partial derivatives, and

\begin{align*}
x&=2t^2, & y&=t^3, & & \\
f_x(2,1)&=5, & f_y(2,1)&=-2, & & \\
f_{xx}(2,1)&=2, & f_{xy}(2,1)&=1, & f_{yy}(2,1)&=-4
\end{align*}

Find $\frac{\textrm{d}^2z}{\textrm{d}t^2}$ when \emph{t=1}.
statement_raw:
Let <math>\displaystyle z=f(x,y)</math>, where <math>\displaystyle f(x,y)</math> has continuous second order partial derivatives, and

:<math>
\begin{align}
x&=2t^2, & y&=t^3, & & \\
f_x(2,1)&=5, & f_y(2,1)&=-2, & & \\
f_{xx}(2,1)&=2, & f_{xy}(2,1)&=1, & f_{yy}(2,1)&=-4
\end{align}
</math>

Find <math>\frac{\textrm{d}^2z}{\textrm{d}t^2}</math> when ''t=1''.
